name: Selenium WebDriver
description: Using Selenium WebDriver in MQE frameworks.
generalInfo:
Selenium automates browsers. That's it!
What you do with that power is entirely up to you. Primarily, it is for automating web applications for testing purposes, but is certainly not limited to just that. Boring web-based administration tasks can (and should!) be automated as well. Selenium has the support of some of the largest browser vendors who have taken (or are taking) steps to make Selenium a native part of their browser. It is also the core technology in countless other browser automation tools, APIs and frameworks.
The biggest change in Selenium recently has been the inclusion of the WebDriver API. Driving a browser natively as a user would either locally or on a remote machine using the Selenium Server it marks a leap forward in terms of browser automation. Selenium WebDriver fits in the same role as RC did, and has incorporated the original 1.x bindings. It refers to both the language bindings and the implementations of the individual browser controlling code. This is commonly referred to as just "WebDriver" or sometimes as Selenium 2. Selenium 1.0 + WebDriver = Selenium 2.0 WebDriver is designed in a simpler and more concise programming interface along with addressing some limitations in the Selenium-RC API. WebDriver is a compact Object Oriented API when compared to Selenium1.0 It drives the browser much more effectively and overcomes the limitations of Selenium 1.x which affected our functional test coverage, like the file upload or download, pop-ups and dialogs barrier WebDriver overcomes the limitation of Selenium RC's Single Host origin policy WebDriver is the name of the key interface against which tests should be written in Java, the implementing classes one should use are listed as below: ChromeDriver, EventFiringWebDriver, FirefoxDriver, HtmlUnitDriver, InternetExplorerDriver, PhantomJSDriver, RemoteWebDriver, SafariDriver

questions.text: What is Selenium WebDriver?
What are the different types of locators?
Compare Xpath vs CSS?
Сomplex user gestures emulation. Actions class.
How to execute JavaScript with Selenium?
Types of Wait in WebDriver. Difference between Implicit and Explicit Wait?
What is Fluent Wait? Fluent Wait configuration.
What is Page Object pattern?
What is Page Component Object pattern?
Page Objects: Composition vs Inheritance? When to use?
Selenium DesiredCapabilities?
Browser commands, Browser Navigation commands.
Selenium Grid. How to start hub, nodes?
How to run tests in parallel?

selfStudyQuestions.text: What is Page Factory? FindBy(s) annotation.
What is Fluent style page object?
What is ThreadLocal? What is InheritedThreadlocal?

acceptanceCriteria.text: Basic understanding how Selenium WebDriver works.
Knowledge how to start drivers for different browsers.
Knowledge of WebDriver interface API.
Knowledge of Page Object, Page Component Object patterns.
Understanding of using Page Object Composition and Inheritance.
Knowledge of Implicit and Explicit waits, Fluent waits.
Understanding how to run tests in parallel.
Understanding of ThreadLocal and when it can be used.
Knowledge of Actions, JavaScriptExecutor classes.
Understanding what is Selenium Grid, how to start and configure hub, nodes.

tasks.text: Implement test suite with 2 test scripts for checking login/logout process to Mail.

subItems.text: at least 3 checks should be done for each test
use Fluent Wait for page loading, elements waiting
use Page Object, Page Compontents Object patterns
use Action for at least one user actions
use javascript (e.g. for clicking on any button)
run all tests in one thread for one browser

tasks.text: Add support for multithread execution. Run your tests in parallel.
Add DriverFactory to support both Firefox, Chrome. Run each test for both browsers (Factory, DataProvider).
(Additional) Add getting run environment info (browser) from configuration/property file.
(Additional) Move driver start and termination to TestListener.
(Additional) Implement next test scenario with all requirements from task 1.

subItems.text: create a new mail (fill in the fields: address, subject, body)
save the mail as a draft
verify that the mail is present in the ‘Drafts’ folder
verify the draft content (address, subject and body)
verify that the mail disappeared from the ‘Drafts’ folder
verify that the mail is in the ‘Sent’ folder
verify that user is not logged in

name: Proxy
description: Using proxy in TAF. Charles Proxy.

questions.text: What is a Proxy server and how does it work?
What is HTTP Protocol?
HTTP Request methods, Status codes, Request and Response message format?
HTTP vs HTTPS? What is SSL and what are SSL certificates?

Proxy Tool: Rewrite, No Caching, Map Remote.
Proxy configuration: External Proxies.
What is HAR file?
What is BrowserMob Proxy?

acceptanceCriteria.text: Understanding what is Proxy Server and how does it work.
Knowledge of HTTP/HTTPS protocol.
Knowledge what is Browser Mob Proxy.
Knowledge of Charles Proxy.
Understanding what is HAR file.
Understanding how to add Rewrite rule.
Ability to set up sniffing traffic HTTP/HTTPS traffic on mobile device.

tasks.text: Start BrowserMob Proxy server for Firefox WebDriver.
Open any url and collect session data to HAR file.
Add response body rewrite.
Add getRequests(String urlPattern) method that will return list of HarRequests by some pattern from Har object.
Configure mobile device to use Charles as a proxy. Setup HTTP/HTTPS traffic sniffing (use Charles SSL Certificate for HTTPS). Install certificate for Android, iOS 9, 10+ devices.
Add rewrite rule to Charles: add new header to all requests from device.
Configure External Proxy in Charles.

subItems.text: Page objects and tests, test data

knowledgeTransfer.text: Short intro into common classes that are used in all MQE frameworks: CapabilityFactory,  listeners, proxy utils, AppLib, Config, TestIDs, TestRun, BaseTest.

Intro to ...Interact classes. List of available Interacts (WebInteract, MobileInteract and etc.). Show where to find method implementation in mqe-core-server. Web(Mobile)Interact implementation features and waiters.

Into into Allure configurations and how to use Allure report.
Rerunning failed tests, integration with Allure report.

How is Apache Commons library used in the framework?

questions.text: What is Version control?
Benefits of version control system?
Types of VCS?
What is Git? Why is git popular?
How to set up a repository?
Git configuration – user name, user email?
How to configure access to Git repo via SSH?
Possible file states? Working directory/Staging area(Index)/Repository.
How to save changes?
What is .gitignore file?
Sync with remote repository (git pull, git fetch).
Using branches.
What is Pull Request(PR)? Making a PR.
How to merge changes (git merge)?
What is merge conflict? How to resolve merge it?
Undoing changes in working directory, staging area.

selfStudyQuestions.text: Popular git hosting systems(sites)? Github, bitbucket.
Undoing changes (part 2): local commit, remote commit.

notes.text: Identify yourself ( set user name, user email via git config)
Don’t forget to pull before push (will save you from unnecessary merges and your changes should be tested  with latest changes, that were made by teammates)
Use command line to understand how git works
Don’t commit temporary and system files (tests output, logs, target folder with binaries, IDE and system files like .idea, .DS_Store and others)
Use branches and understand benefits of branching
Decrease development overheads (short commits, often merging)
Don’t use –f parameter for git push if you don’t understand what it is

acceptanceCriteria.text: Understanding what is Git and it’s benefits
Understanding of Git workflow
Understanding of changes states and workflow (Working directory/Staging area(Index)/Repository)
Ability to work with Git via command line
Ability to set up, clone a repo
Ability to pull changes from remote repository
Understanding and using .gitignore file
Understanding and using branches
Ability to create Pull Requests, merge branches, resolve conflicts
Ability to undo local changes

tasks.text: Create public repo on Github (create a new repo on the command line according with steps described on Github - repo with README.md file in ‘master’ branch).
Configure your repo: set user name and user email.
Create branches with branch name ‘develop’, ‘test’ and push it to the remote repo.
Delete branch ‘test’ from local and remote repo.
Create .gitignore file in ‘master’ branch, add ignoring any folder, commit to local repo.
Create .gitignore file in ‘develop’ branch, add ignoring any file, commit to local repo.
Merge ‘develop’ branch to ‘master’ branch. Resolve conflict. Push to remote repo.
Delete .gitignore file from master branch. Don’t commit. Undo deleting.
Delete .gitignore file from master branch. Commit changes to local repo. Undo local commit.
Remove your local repo and clone it from Github.

Undo latest commit from local master branch, remove changes from working directory, update README.md file, push to remote master branch. Conflict should appear. Read git instructions (should present in terminal). What is –f parameter? Pull remote master branch to your local and push updated README.md file to remote repo again. No issues should appear.

acceptanceCriteria.text: Understanding what is Maven and how it works.
Knowledge what are dependencies and dependency hierarchy.
Knowledge of 3 types of repositories (local, central, remote).
Understanding how to configure access to remote repository (settings.xml).
Understanding Maven lifecycle (what happens on each phase).
Knowledge basic Maven plugins and it’s purpose (compiler/surefire/checkstyle plugins).
Understanding what is local repository and how find it.
Knowledge how to exclude dependency.

tasks.text: Create a Maven project.
Add dependencies to POM file: TestNG, Selenium, Log4j. Use command line to load dependencies from Central Repository. Check if dependency is loaded to .m2 folder.
Create 2 simple tests.
Set target compile version.
Run single test with Maven Surefire plugin.
Run group of tests with Maven Surefire plugin.
Find list of TestNG dependencies (you can use Maven Central Repository or Dependency Hierarchy/Tree in your IDE).
Exclude jcommander from TestNG dependency (<exclusions> tag). Check that  jcommander should present in Dependency Hierarchy any more.
Install JAR of your Maven project to your local repo. Check that dependency with your artifactId and groupId appeared in your local repository.

name: TestNG
generalInfo:
TestNG is a testing framework inspired from JUnit and NUnit but introducing some new functionalities that make it more powerful and easier to use:
- Annotations.
- Run your tests in arbitrarily big thread pools with various policies available (all methods in their own thread, one thread per test class, etc...).
- Test that your code is multithread safe.
- Flexible test configuration.
- Support for data-driven testing (with @DataProvider).
- Support for parameters.
- Powerful execution model (no more TestSuite).
- Supported by a variety of tools and plug-ins (Eclipse, IDEA, Maven, etc...).
- Embeds BeanShell for further flexibility.
- Default JDK functions for runtime and logging (no dependencies).
- Dependent methods for application server testing.
- TestNG is designed to cover all categories of tests: unit, functional, end-to-end, integration, etc...

questions.text: What is TestNG? How does it works.
What is testing.xml file used for?
What are the annotations available in TestNG?
What is the difference between Hard and Soft Assertions?
How to parameterize test?
What is DataProvider?
What is TestNG Factory? What is the difference from DataProvider?
What are TestNG Listeners and how can you use them (ISuiteListener, ITestListener, IMethodInterceptor)?
How does IAnnorationTransformer listener can be used?
How to rerun failed test (IRetryAnalyzer)?
What is Dependent Test? When tests dependency can be used?
How to configure dependent test on other method/test group?
What is test priority? How to set up test priority?
How to run tests in parallel?
How to disable a test?
How to skip a test?
How to run tests programmatically?

acceptanceCriteria.text: Understanding what is TestNG.
Knowledge of TestNG annotations.
Ability to configure test groups, tests dependency.
Understanding of difference between Soft and Hard Asserts.
Understanding of Factory and DataProvider, difference between them.
Understanding of basic listeners and how they can be used: ISuiteListener, ITestListener, IAnnotationTransformer, IMethodInterceptor.
Knowledge how to run tests in parallel.
Knowledge how to run TestNG programmatically.
Knowledge what is IRetryAnalyzer.

tasks.text: Create a test сlass with one test method configured with DataProvider. Create one more test that is dependent on the first one. How much times will be ran each test?
Create a new test class with test method. Integrate TestNG Factory to this test.
Create a new test with 2 independent test methods, then add the same group to both tests. Run both tests by group.
Create a new test with parameters from testng.xml file.
Add listeners: TestListener, SuiteListener and AnnotationTransformer (use separate class for each listener).
Add logging that suite started (SuiteListener). Use Log4j for logging.
Add logging that test started and finished in format: class name + test name + “started/finished”. Class and test names should be dynamic, don’t hardcode (TestListener).
Add logging list of annotations used for test method (AnnotationTransformer).
Create your custom annotation, mark any 2 tests with this annotation.
Disable tests that are marked with your custom annotation (TestAnnotationTransformer).
At the suite finish add logging duration in milliseconds for each test method.

tasks.text: Create a test сlass with one test method configured with DataProvider. Create one more test that is dependent on the first one. How much times will be ran each test?
Create a new test class with test method. Integrate TestNG Factory to this test.
Create a new test with 2 independent test methods, then add the same group to both tests. Run both tests by group.
Create a new test with parameters from testng.xml file.
Add listeners: TestListener, SuiteListener and AnnotationTransformer (use separate class for each listener).
Add logging that suite started (SuiteListener). Use Log4j for logging.
Add logging that test started and finished in format: class name + test name + “started/finished”. Class and test names should be dynamic, don’t hardcode (TestListener).

Disable tests that are marked with your custom annotation (TestAnnotationTransformer).
At the suite finish add logging duration in milliseconds for each test method.

name: Unit testing general info
generalInfo: UNIT TESTING is a level of software testing where individual units/ components of a software are tested. The purpose is to validate that each unit of the software performs as designed. A unit is the smallest testable part of any software. It usually has one or a few inputs and usually a single output. In procedural programming, a unit may be an individual program, function, procedure, etc. In object-oriented programming, the smallest unit is a method, which may belong to a base/ super class, abstract class or derived/ child class. (Some treat a module of an application as a unit. This is to be discouraged as there will probably be many individual units within that module.) Unit testing frameworks, drivers, stubs, and mock/ fake objects are used to assist in unit testing.

Add logging that test started and finished in format: class name + test name + “started/finished”. Class and test names should be dynamic, don’t hardcode (TestListener).
Add logging list of annotations used for test method (AnnotationTransformer).
Create your custom annotation, mark any 2 tests with this annotation.
Disable tests that are marked with your custom annotation (TestAnnotationTransformer).
At the suite finish add logging duration in milliseconds for each test method.
